 As a person with a slightly jaded past myself, I'm sympathetic to the plight of people who for some reason or another, got caught up on the business end of the Criminal Justice System and wound up with a Felony record. As everbody knows, here in the US, having a felony record is akin to a second life sentence, but without the bars.
 
 
 Legislation is right now making the rounds through Congress known as the "Second Chance Act of 2007" And one key provision would prohibit prospective employers from going any further back than seven years on a background check.
 
 As you all know, I am fairly Conservative in my worldview, and I believe this to be in line with that because:
 
 1) it allows ex cons, parolees, and probationers to seek and get good jobs without the handicap
 
 2) Society benefits because when aforementioned people are working meaningful jobs, being taxpayers instead of burdens, and contributing to the overall fabric of society, guess what! Recidvism rates go down.
 
 
 Thoughts?

 You might also point out to the naysayers that criminal background checks by employers are a fairly new thing. Until 15 or 20 years ago, a criminal background chedck on somebody was a massive affair. Only the DOJ really had the resources to carry out a complete background check on individuals on a routine basis because there was no central clearing house for the data. Often times the only way to determine a persons criminal history was to go to everyplace they have ever lived and pull the local court records. Today all that information is centralized and it takes 2 minutes on the internet and a paid subscription to a web page and you can have a persons entire cirminal history.
 
 The #1 compnent in determining whether a person is going to be a repeat offender or not is their ability to get a good job. A lot of people come out of jail with their outlook changed. They don't want to go back. Then they end up flipping burgers for minimum wage because they can't get a job anywhere else and they become disillusioned. They end up commiting a crime and end up back in jail.
 
 For the first roughly 210 years of this nations history people could do their time, get out of jail, and start over....move to a new town if they had to. Today MOST of our criminals are repeat offenders. Prior to the 1980's, VERY few of our criminals were repeat offenders. People got out of jail, went "####....I am never going to do that again", and built a new life. What we do by giving employers access to a complete criminal history on people is ensuring that individuals today can not do that. Once you take away a persons ability to start a new life and move ahead based on hard work, what is left for them?
 
 Personally, I have hired a LOT of people in the past and have never run a criminal background check on any of them. My applications did not even have a place for "criminal history". It has never caused me any problems. I had an accountant at my business who 2 years after I hired him told me that he had been convicted of a felony. Embezzlement, no less. When I hired him he was working at the local meatopacking plant which was a little unusual since he had a degree in accounting and a lot of experience in that field, but not unusual enough to really throw any red flags. I figured he was a corporate burnout. I thappens. I once had a framing carpenter who worked for me that had a PhD and had been a VP at a fortune 500 company. He burned out and ended up framing houses for about 6 years, then he went back into the corporate world. 
 
 The accountant never stole from me, and I don't regret having hired him. He apparentyl figured I knew about his conviction, but I didn't. He assumed I did a criminal background check. I didn't. I figure that crimes that people have committed are none of my business if they have already served their sentence. That is the way it is supposed to be.

However, if the recidivism rate is still high, then I think that employers have a right to know.
